summary.seg: This manuscript contains texts in Greek and Latin, Homilies and grammatical texts; it is formed by three parts, all produced in the 15th century.
Part I (ff. 1:1-1:20) contains two homilies attributed to Epiphanius, bishop of Salamis (Constantia) in Cyprus (ca. 310-403 CE), but considered spurious, about the burial of Christ and Palm-Sunday.

In part II (ff. 2:1-2:15) there is the first book of the Greek grammar by Theodore Gaza (or Gazes), a 15th-century Byzantine scholar from Thessalonike (ca. 1415-1475/6). He settled in Italy, where he worked as a teacher (he was lecturer in Greek at the University of Ferrara), becoming one of the leading figures in Greek studies in Renaissance Italy. His Greek grammar ( Eisagogé), became very popular among humanists all over Europe. Only the first book of this work is present in the manuscript. The text, in King's MS 10, was copied by a well-known scribe of the 15th century, Ioannes Rhosos. Born in Crete, he was active in Italy as a professional scribe, working in various cities, as Rome, Venice, Bologna, Florence, Grottaferrata, for important personalities, such as Palla Strozzi, Francesco Gonzaga and Lorenzo il Magnifico (see RGK I, 178). Ioannes Rhosos copied Gaza's grammar several times; in Cambridge a complete copy of this work in his hand is preserved in MS University Library, Ii.4.16.

The last part of the manuscript (III, ff. 2:16-2:112) contains a handbook, defined Encheiridion by its author, containing grammatical, rhetorical observations, and various texts, such as occasional poems, written in Latin, with some parts in Greek, by a certain Domitius (or Dominicus) Almartius (de Almarza). The script and the watermark allow to date also this part of the manuscript in the 15th century, probably in the first half.

supportDesc.foliation: Two endleaves, one at the beginning, one at the end of the manuscript, are unnumbered: ff. [i] and [ii]. There are two modern pencil foliations, in Arabic numerals, in the upper margin, right, recto (here labeled respectively as 1 and 2): 1 to 20 ( ff. 1:1r-1:20r), and 1 to 112 (109 and 110 are not present because two leaves are missing: ff. 2:1r-2:112r). The leaves are numbered as follows: [i] + 1:1-1:20 + 2:1-2:108, 2:111-2:112 + [ii]

condition.p: The manuscript is in good condition. F. 1:1r is heavily stained. Big portions of ff. 2:106 and 2:111 have been lost. Two leaves have been lost (ff. 109-110), without affecting the texts.

additions.p: On the left pastedown there are modern pencil annotations: the shelfmark MS. 10 and 26.A.3, as well as an annotation concerning the donation of the manuscript to the College by John Pearson (see History), preceded by the signature, 10, in a brown ink.

binding.p:
Western modern binding, full parchment cover over couched-laminate boards. Black tooling on spine with title in the upper part, Epiphanii Sermones Graece, and in the lower Ms. Saec. XV. On the lower part of the spine is pasted a label with shelfmark 10.
280 210 37
binding.condition: There is a hole through the left board near the foredge. The manuscript was rebound, as stated in a note written in pencil on the right pastedown, Rebound V.A. Brown Hildeborough April 1948.

accMat.p: Two later endleaves are present, one at the beginning and one at the end of the manuscript, f. [i] and f. [ii]; they are both blank. They are made of western paper, folded in-folio. On f. [ii] an unidentified watermark is visible: a circle containing letters (?) I C ( 35 35 ).

In the manuscript, between the left pastedown and f. [i], are kept a paper leaf containing a bibliographical reference about a text present in the manuscript, and an envelope containing 4 modern pieces of paper with descriptions of parts of the manuscript and bibliographical references.

history.provenance:
The manuscript was owned by the theologian
John Pearson (1613-1686) Pearson, John, 1613-1686 , Master of Jesus (1660-1662) and Trinity College (1662-1673), bishop of Chester.
history.acquisition: John Pearson donated the codex to King's College, as stated in a note written on the left pastedown : Dedit Reverendus Ioannes Pearson S. Theologiae Professor, Collegii SS. Trinitatis Magister, hujus Collegii nuper socius. A similar note is written also in another manuscript donated by Pearson to the College, MS Cambridge, King's College, 7, where it is accompanied by the mention of the year 1665 (see James 1895, p. 13). It can be therefore assumed that also MS King's 10 was donated around the same year and, in any case, in the years 1662-1673, since in the note Pearson is cited as Master of Trinity College. On the left pastedown is pasted the King's College bookplate.

recordHist.source: Description (2020) draws partly on M.R. James, A descriptive catalogue of the Manuscripts other than Oriental in the Library of King's College, Cambridge, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1895, pp. 14-20.

availability.p: Visitors to King's College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: King's College Library.

monogr.title: A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts other than Oriental in the library of King's College, Cambridge

analytic.title: Ένα ξόρκι για τους ποντικούς από τον 15ο αιώνα

monogr.title: Repertorium der griechischen Kopisten, 800-1600. I. Grossbritannien

imprint.publisher: Verlag der Österreichischen Akademie der Wissenschaften

msItem.title: Homilia in divini corporis sepulturam
msItem.note: The text is attributed to Epiphanius (ca. 310-403) Epiphanius, Saint, Bishop of Constantia in Cyprus, approximately 310-403 but is considered spurious
msItem.rubric: f. 1:2r Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Ἐπιφανίου ἐπισκόπου Κύπρου· λόγος εἰς τὴν θεόσομον ταφὴν τοῦ κυρίου ἡμῶν Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ· καὶ εἰς τὸν Ἰωσὴφ τὸν ἀπὸ Ἀριμαθείας· καὶ εἰς τὴν ἐν ἅδῃ Χριστοῦ τοῦ κατάβασιν μετὰ τὸ σωτήριον πάθος γεναμένην
msItem.incipit: f. 1:2r Τί τοῦτο σήμερον σιγὴ πολλὴ ἐν τῆ γῇ
msItem.explicit: f. 1:13v νῦν καὶ ἀεὶ καὶ εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων ἀμήν.

msItem.title: Homilia in festo palmarum
msItem.note: The text is attributed to Epiphanius (ca. 310-403) Epiphanius, Saint, Bishop of Constantia in Cyprus, approximately 310-403 but is considered spurious
msItem.rubric: f. 1:14r Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Ἐπιφανείου ἐπισκόπου Κύπρου, λόγος εἰς τὰ Βαΐα. Κύριε εὐλόγησον
msItem.incipit: f. 1:14r Χαῖρε σφόδρα θύγατερ Σιὼν, τέρπου καὶ ἀγάλλου
msItem.explicit: f. 1:18v Αὐτῶ ἡ δόξα σὺν τῶ πατρὶ, καὶ τῶ πνεύματι εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας ἀμήν.

support.material:
Western paper, folded in folio.
Watermarks:
ff. 1:1-1:4, 1:6-1:7, 1:9-1:12 Bell ( ca. 65 32 ), in the centre of the leaf, comparable to Harlfinger Cloche 13, 16 , which are dated in 1412 and 1446.
ff. 1:5/1:8, 1:14-1:19 Three mountains in a circle surmounted by a hooked cross ( 70 36 ), in the centre of the leaf, no exact parallels found in the main repertoires, but see Briquet Monts 11851-11897 , which are dated in 1376-1476.
ff. 1:13/1:20 Three mountains in a double circle surmounted by an upright ( 80 40 ), in the centre of the leaf, comparable to Wasserzeichen Informatonssystem Dreiberg im Kreisring DE6255-PO-154188 , which is however surmounted by a cross, and is dated to 1418, and to Briquet, Monts 11898 , which is dated in 1417-1427, and to Harlfinger, Monts 93a and 93b , which are dated in 1431.

collation.p: Part I is formed by two quires, a senion and a quaternion

handNote.p: ff. 1:2r-1:18v Hand A: the texts in part I have been written in a script belonging to the traditional-conservative strand of Greek scripts, which exhibit characteristics of the τῶν Ὁδηγῶν (ton Hodegon) style. The script is datable in the 15th c.
The text is written in brown ink; titles and initials in red.

decoDesc.decoNote: On f. 1:2r there is a rectangular headpiece in red ink, with clovers at the corners, filled by a geometrical motif of interlaced rhombuses.
On f. 1:14r there is a frieze in red ink with a chain motif.
Initials in ekthesis are decorated with a branch motif, see ff. 1:2r, 1:14r).

additions.p: On f. 1:1r there are scattered notes and pen trials in Latin and in Greek. The shelfmark 10 is present as well.
On f. 1:19v the beginning of the Nicene Creed is written three times in Greek by an anonymuous annotator.

On f. 1:20v there is a long annotation (10 lines) in modern Greek written in Latin alphabet; the hand seems the same who wrote annotations in Latin on f. 1:1r. On this text, with a transcription and translitteration in Greek, see Κακουλίδη 1959. It is a dialogue between two persons, a master and an exorcist.

history.origin: This part of the manuscript, judging by script and watermarks, was copied in the 15th century, probably in the first half, or around the middle of the century.

msItem.author: Gazes, Theodoros
msItem.title: Introduction to Grammar, book I
Grammaticae Introductio, I
msItem.rubric: f. 2:1r Θεοδώρου Γραμματικῆς Εἰσαγωγῆς. Τῶν εἰς τέσσαρα τὸ αον
msItem.incipit: f. 2:1r Τῶν τεσσάρων καὶ εἴκοσι γραμμάτων
msItem.explicit: f. 2:15r ὁ δὲ σύνθετος, οἷον ἐπειδή.
msItem.note: Ed. Theodori grammatices libri IIII. De mensibus liber eiusdem. Georgii Lecapeni de constructione verborum. Emmanuelis Moschopuli de constructione nominum et verborum. Eiusdem de accentibus, Venice 1525, ff. 1-144

support.material:
Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermarks:
ff. 2:1-2:8 Traces of watermark, difficult to decipher in the gutter.
ff. 2:9-2:15 Bird (duck?) ( 50 ca. 40 ), in the centre of the leaf and in the gutter , comparable to Harlfinger Oiseau 6 and 7 , which are dated in 1479 and 1475, and which were found in manuscripts copied by Ioannes Rhosos.

collation.p: Part II consists of two quaternions.

list.item: Quire 48-1 ff. 2:9-2:15(βον. The 8th leaf is missing)

collation.signatures: There are original quire signatures in Greek numerals, by the scribe, on the first folio of each quire, recto, lower centre, and the last folio of each quire, verso, lower centre: αον (ff. 2:1r and 2:8v) and βον (f. 2:9r).

handNote.p:
ff. 2:1r-2:15r Hand B: the text in part II was copied by
Ioannes Rhosos (active 1450-1498) Iōannēs Rhōsos, active 1450-1498
(Ἰωάννης Ῥῶσος, RGK I, 178. On him see also RGK II, 237; RGK III, 298).
The text is written in a light brown ink; titles and initials in red.

decoDesc.decoNote: The beginning of the text is preceded by a rectangular headpiece in red ink, with plaited ornament ( f. 2:1r).

On f. 2:1r there is a large initial in red ink with a plaited, branch decoration. Minor initials in red ink, often with simple vegetal ornament, are present throughout the text (see e.g. ff. 2:2r, 2:3r); they have sometimes infill in translucent yellow wash (see e.g. f. 2:7v).
Shorter lines are frequently completed with simple line-fillers in red ink, see ff. 2:3r, 2:6r. On f. 2:3r there is a frieze in a rope motif, in red ink.
In the margins are present small patterns of scrolling ornament in red ink, see e.g. f. 2:3r.

history.origin: The text of this part of the manuscript was copied by Ioannes Rhosos, who was active in Italy in the second half of the 15th century.

msItem.title: Encheiridion by Domitius Almartius
msItem.note:
In the upper margin of f. 2:16r are written two titles:
Apochriφα Domitiana
Domitius Almartius Sorias ad praeceptorem, athletas (?) et sodales Encheiridion
msItem.incipit: f. 2:16r Dominicus de Almarza gymnastico suo Soriati Iohanni de Nyena et eique sodalibus ac athletis salutem
msItem.note: The text is a sort of grammatical, rhetorical handbook in Latin, with some parts in Greek, and a collection of various poetical texts, in 8 books, the first part is a dedication letter from Domitius (or Dominicus) Almartius to the praeceptor Iohannes Sorias (?) de Nyena
The scribe wrote in the margins annotations in Latin and in Greek

msItem.title: Book 3
msItem.rubric: f. 2:33v Libellus tertius de adverbiis et aliis particulis

msItem.title: Book 5
msItem.rubric: f. 2:56v Sequitur quintus libellus Enchiridiorum longe praeter diplomata ad disapertum Almartium fratrem

msItem.title: Book 6
msItem.rubric: f. 2:75r Liber sextus ex Apocriphis ad sodales Soriates

msItem.title: Book 7
msItem.rubric: f. 2:83v Liber septimus ad Morosum fratrem et tyrones Soriates de scansione et syllabarum quantitate et nonnullis sylvis et epigrammatis epithome

support.material:
Western paper, folded in folio. Watermarks:
ff. 2:16-2:112 Flower containing a six-point star, with stem ( 55 35 ), in the centre of the leaf, similar to Briquet, Fleur 6693, which is dated in 1484-1489 (Italy).

collation.p: Part III consists of septernions and quinions, alternating.

list.item: Quire 1210-2 ff. 2:102-2:111( ff. 109-110 are missing, stubs remain, no loss of text)

collation.signatures: Modern indications: a small cross has been traced in pencil in the lower margin, right, of the first leaf verso of the second part of each quire.

handNote.p: ff. 2:16r-2:102v Hand C: the Greek text has been written in an informal minuscule script by the same scribe who wrote the test in Latin. The script is upright, letters are divided, the ductus is not very rapid and fluent.
The text has been written in a brown ink.

decoDesc.decoNote: Thick initials in ekthesis in brown ink, see e.g. f. 2:72r.

additions.p: On the lower edge of f. 2:106v there is a note in Italian written upside down, Messer Francesco salutovi tamen (?) sapiate, come hanno roto la casa vostra.
On the lower edge of f. 2:111r there is a note in Latin, written upside down, where the name Mr. Gotherne can be read ( James 1898, p. 20).
On f. 2:112v there are some Greek memoranda, citing the dates of 18 February and 9 April 1632, with a list of names and quantities: probably accounts.

history.origin: The watermark of the paper suggests, for this part of the manuscript, a date in the second half of the 15th c.
